column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$4$"I am 32 M.

column1: I have also been an addict since I was in my early teen's. Alcohol/weed/LSD/XtC/and on and on.....
I graduated into Harder drugs. Opiates Eg.Heroin
column2: oxycontin
column3: Morphine.

column1: But stimulant drugs have been my #1 worst of all my addictions.I Have been a Hardcore cocaine/Crack addict now for 15years.
I was Diagnosed with ADD at the age of 8. I was put on many alternatives with no help until trying Ritalin.
Ritalin (XR) helped with many symptoms and behaviour issues. But within two years  began to fail because of my tolerance. & again back to old behaviours.

I lived in small town southern Ontario Growing up.Even though my family life was fairly normal with 2 sisters & both loving parents.  My life was a wreck. In and out of jail. I flopped out of school and into drugs.
By 25 I was in Jail for two counts of robbery because of a crack addiction.
I ended up in North America's worst place for any person with drug addiction to Move to.
Vancouver's notorious (DTES) Downtown East Side.
The point to this is now I have been almost 3 years off Crack/coke.  And it's because that 3 years  ago I went on Dexedrine and was able to get my life back with therapy

and medication so for me it saved my life. It does have addictive properties but when on the right dose it can be very affective.After reaching a dose both My doctor and I were both comfortable with. As tolerance is concerned it has not become a problem.  I've been on the same dose for all that time.

38$Condition: Other$6/25/2011 12:53:11 PM$Reviewer: Aarius
column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$4$"Rx for over 6 months now. Have had to work a little to adjust dosage. This trial at 10 Mg Sustained Action capsules 4 times a day.  I am a Vietnam Era Veteran with a long history of indicated Rx medications combined with a natural high tolerance. I am also well educated and a responsible VA patient.  About 6 weeks into this regimen I realized I needed to talk with my prescriber. I was not realizing prescribed bioavailability. (Rx not working as MD intended.) A once a day 10 Mg tablet
column3: not sustained release
column4: prescribed as an intended balancing effort.  We found my comfort zone.  Now my diagnosed condition is treated and regular medical attention to monitor ongoing progress is documented. Perhaps as with any Rx I do have some issues
column5: one of which gets me a confused look from my regular MD prescriber.  With the SA Caps I will sometimes not be able to take them at the same time every day. I have enough experience now to point definitively to this medication. Dextroamphetamine is a CNS stimulant and as such should elevate sensory functions.  The SA Caps are designed to have a lesser degree of quick release with a leveling off action.  I take them as prescribed and within 40 to 50 minutes I can hardly keep my eyes open.  My research shows a similar reaction young people experience with Ritalin.  It is ""Speed""
column6: yet it calms the hyper child down.  I have no empirical evidence and have not found anyone who has like experiences. Perhaps this post will help.  This medication in no way diminishes my appetite or waistline. MD/patient discussion on this is in accord. While I do get therapeutic value
column7: I am actually well below my own tolerance level.  The medication loses the battle big time at the fridge. I do experience expected though very unwanted side effects. Elevated but well monitored BP. Tenderness in male reproductive area. Mild systemic nerve parasthesia if I forget to dose and I do. No overwhelming desire to mow the lawn at 4 am. My grade for my diagnosis

column1: 39$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$5/20/2011 12:40:05 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$"i havent been on any other treatment but i found that when we got the dosage figured out i really do love it. i dont have any side effects besides loss of appetite

column3: im still my bubbly self
column4: i just get my work and school work done! as im getting into the hard stuff in the RN program i am so thankful for the medication and the positive aspects! "

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$i was on 30 mg adderal tabs before this medication and i went crazy really crazy the adderall almost ruind my marrage i was in my room feeling so weird as if i was looking out of somone eles eyes for six months then my new psychiatrist recomended dextroamphetomine tabs not the xr but the normal ones at first for like four months i didnt want to be a guinie pig but then i tried it its the best thing ive ever done i am a 26 year old woman with severe add and severe narcolepsy and this medication saved my life my marrage now im a good mother wife and person so trust me this medication is worth trying i can stay up during the day yet go to bed and sleep all night i can concentrate on more then one task at a time and im just a more alert calmer person sorry bout the spelling errors typing a little fast i hope this helps sombody out there

column1: 62$Condition: Recurring Sleep Episodes During the Day$4/23/2009 9:33:42 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$2$5$"I've been taking Dexedrine 30mg in the morning and 5-10mg around lunchtime
column2: if needed for about 5-6 years.  Prior to that
column3: I took Provigil [really liked it
column4: but it is no longer available on my pharmcy formulary]
column5: Ritalin [hated the side effects-mostly shakiness and it didn't seem to work well].  When I first started taking it
column6: the results were great! No bad side effects
column7: either.  The loss of appetite is NOT a negative one for me :).  Howwever
column9: I've found I can wake in the morning
column10: eat breakfast and take my meds - then
column11: fall sound asleep for another few hours - unless I somehow force myself to get up and stay up.  My job was ""down-sized"" about 8 months ago
column12: so most days I don't HAVE to get up at any particular time.  I went so far as to check my pills to be sure somehow I wasn't getting a placebo.  As far as I can tell.. and
column13: from what my doctor and the pharmacy tells me - I am taking the same drug and same strength.  They are baffled... I'm really concerned about this.  There are time periods of up to a week that I've taken a break from the drug without any problems stopping or re-starting it.  I wonder if anyone else has had anything similar going on.  Since this isn't an interactive forum
column15: at least let me know if I'm not the only one having this problem..."

71$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$1/8/2009 3:19:11 AM$Reviewer: bobsledd, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$4$This medication i have benifited the most from.It maintained a ballance that others have not.As i have a fast metabolizem,this medication seem to stay in my systom unlike others before.I started taking this medication as a result of worsening conditions brought on by the use of less exspensive medications.Insurance coverage did not allow prescribed medication and sustituded with generic,amphetimine with salts.I found a stabalization that i thought was not possible.When taken as prescribed ,the benefits were miraculas.I do believe certain elements can alter its affectiveness.Extreme heat,causing the release of certain compounds to fast to metabolize.This in turn causes some of the side effects listed above as i experenced this summer do to high tempratures.Sweating out compounds while others biuld up in the systom that can become toxic.The lack of literature given with this medication does not warn of all side affects and precautionary measures.As i mentioned extreme heat for me was not warned on the patient education sheat as well as many more im sure should be described.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$"Have tried many different prescriptions for add before and none have worked as well. Throughout my life I had the same comments said about me. ""He's lazy""
column3: ""Daydreamer""

column1: 79$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$7/5/2008 4:21:30 AM$Reviewer: mike,  Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$With Dexedrine
column2: I am taking a med I self-medicated in the '60s! In 9th grade in '62
column3: I could not stay awake in the AM. My Mom's best friend was a drug salesman and she got Dexamyl for weight. I snitched a few dex 15 mg spansule there and at my corner drugstore job. From teacher and parents
column4: I got the usual ""lazy
column5: no motivation"". Scorn from father who laughed that I would be lawyer. But on Dex
column6: I was honorable mention Merit Scholar.  In college
column7: I remembered ""speed"" and took it to study
column8: carrying virtually an ""A"" average--I was admitted to and graduated a top 10 law school in 1973.I did not take it in Law School
column9: for fear of getting caught and not wanting to use a crutch. My grades were unremarkable. For the next 30 years
column10: I struggled through terrible life events
column11: witn no medication for my horrific AD/HD. During my second divorce
column13: my X demanded I be tested and I was. I got meds and the Dex is like putting eyeglasses on my brain. I take 15 mg 4 times a day--not out of the usual range--I am 200 pound athletic type. I also take bupoprion aka Wellbutrin for my HD--150 SR twice daily. both work just great for me
column15: and the other one--I forget its name--but they were ineffective. I have not tried the new ones and do not plan to do so.I am extremely happy with Dexedrine
column16: having taken it on and off for nigh 45 years--and totally on for the last 6 years.

column1: I get cotton mouth occasionally
column2: or a bad taste. But my side effects are nothing
column3: zero
column4: compared to the benefits. You folks should try the drugs available--don't be shy
column5: since dosage for a person is trial and error for both stimulants and anti depressives. We AD/HD victims are actually a hell of a lot smarter than the Lilliputians insulting us through life. I love the look on their faces when I tell them my legal career has been in DC as counsel to the Senate
column6: House and the White House and various Federal agencies. You will be amazed at what you can do when you can count on yourself--awake!"

column1: 80$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$5/31/2008 8:12:51 PM$Reviewer: des
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"It used to be that no matter how much I tried
column3: I failed!  My family and teachers thought my failures in school were because I was lazy.

column1: School was hard for me.  I would get bored because nothing made any sense
column2: I could try with every fiber of my being to pay attention and understand what my teachers told me (sometimes only out of respect of my friends around me trying to listen and work) but I just couldn't do it!

column1: I remember often telling myself 'okay
column2: this is the day that it's all going to make sense
column3: and you're gonna get it' but much to my disappointment I'd find myself totally confused and embarassed to ask questions
column4: mostly because I didn't even always know which part I was confused about!

column1: This happened with all subjects too!  I could be VERY interested and engaged in the class and would still walk away learning only a fraction of what my peers did!  I thought I was mentally retarded and worked very hard at seeming smarter than I really was so that people/teachers wouldn't learn my 'secret' and send me to 'special'
column2: now I sometimes they had!

column1: I ended up dropping out and getting my GED.
And it wasn't until I went to college and started having the same old troubles again
column2: only this time I was paying for my classes and wasn't ABOUT to flake them off!  I tried everything.  I'd read material over and over and still not understand.  It wasn't until a professor recommended I see my doctor about the having adult ADD.

column1: I explained my problem and told my Dr if it wasn't this I was 'slow' and requested testing.  He found me cognitively sound and agreed w/the possibility of ADD and sent me to be evaluated by a psychologist
column2: who indeed diagnosed me w/ADD.

column1: I'm 29
column2: and I've been taking the med now for five years and have since graduated college and work doing Medical Billing.  A job that requires constant focus and is based on productivity.

column1: I've done my homework
column2: and I honestly believe that I would not be able to do the work I love doing w/o Dexidrine!"
